item.title: Compact Operators and Spectral Intuition
item.description: Functional analysis has a reputation for being abstract and “soft”. But once you internalise compact operators on Hilbert spaces, a lot of the theory suddenly feels almost finite-dimensional again. This post is a somewhat opinionated walkthrough of: compact operators on Hilbert spaces, the structure of their spectrum, and how to think about them using finite-dimensional approximations and a bit of code. Along the way we’ll sprinkle some numerical experiments and quotes, to make it feel less like lecture notes and more like a working notebook.

item.title: Quotients, Intuitively
item.description: Quotients are one of those ideas that appear everywhere. At a very crude level, a quotient is what you get when you declare some points to be the same. item.description: Some things I listened to this week: An annoyingly catchy pop album A dense modern jazz record that I only half-understand A string quartet where the harmonic language felt weirdly “probabilistic” One recurring thought: a lot of music feels like it is exploring a space of transformations rather than a fixed melody. item.title: A Note on Reading Mathematics
item.description: People often talk about reading mathematics as if it were like reading a novel. It really is not. A more realistic model: you are trying to compress a long argument into a small, robust mental structure. That requires: Skimming for global structure Filling in local details where your intuition fails Trying to reproduce the argument from memory The posts on this site are written with that workflow in mind: they should be easy to skim, but also withstand careful reading.
